docs.lead_paragraph: A charge of fraud involving 26 articles was leveled by the University of Connecticut against Dipak K. Das, whose work reported health benefits in red wine.

headline.seo: Fraud Charges for Dipak K. Das, a University of Connecticut Researcher
headline.main: University Suspects Fraud by a Researcher Who Studied Red Wine
headline.print_headline: University Suspects Fraud by a Researcher Who Studied Red Wine

docs.abstract: University of Connecticut charges Dipak K Das with widespread scientific fraud related to 26 articles he published related to his work studying the health benefits of wine; University says it will return two new grants issued to Das that are worth a total of $890,000.
docs.snippet: A charge of fraud involving 26 articles was leveled by the University of Connecticut against Dipak K. Das, whose work reported health benefits in red wine.

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers have identified new assessment scales to determine the likelihood of death within six months to five years, helping doctors avoid overtesting and overtreatment of older patients.

headline.seo: Using Interactive Tools to Assess the Likelihood of Death
headline.main: Interactive Tools to Assess the Likelihood of Death
headline.print_headline: Interactive Tools Used to Assess the Likelihood of Death

docs.abstract: Researchers identify new assessment scales to determine likelihood of death within six months to five years, helping doctors avoid overtesting and overtreatment of older patients; fashion interactive tools of the most accurate and useful assessments; study is published in The Journal of the American Medical Association and posted on Web site.
docs.snippet: Researchers have identified new assessment scales to determine the likelihood of death within six months to five years, helping doctors avoid overtesting and overtreatment of older patients.

keywords.value: Journal of the American Medical Assn
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: The economic downturn reined in the growth of health spending as many people lost jobs, income and health insurance, the government said in a report.

headline.seo: Health Spending Held Down by Recession

docs.abstract: Obama administration report published in the journal Health Affairs shows that the recession in 2007-2009 reined in the growth of health spending as many people lost jobs, income and health insurance; graph highlights rates of national spending on health in 2010.
docs.snippet: The economic downturn reined in the growth of health spending as many people lost jobs, income and health insurance, the government said in a report.

docs.lead_paragraph: A new book called “30 Lessons for Living” draws from interviews with more than 1,000 older Americans from different economic, educational and occupational strata.

headline.seo: Elderly ‘Experts’ Share Life Advice in Cornell Project
headline.main: Advice From Life’s Graying Edge on Finishing With No Regrets
headline.print_headline: Advice From Life’s Graying Edge on Finishing With No Regrets

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column reviews advice drawn from interviews with more than 1,000 older Americans and collected in book 30 Lessons for Living by Karl Pillemer.
docs.snippet: A new book called “30 Lessons for Living” draws from interviews with more than 1,000 older Americans from different economic, educational and occupational strata.
